comments.body: Why wouldn't this have `isAppliedConstraint: true`?
It can be if you think it should. I wasn't really sure what the semantics of minWidth for Paragraph were and wasn't sure if infinity made sense for that.
I think it's ignored.  We really need to re-work the Paragraph API to make actual sense.
Ok. I won't bother adding the extra assert here then since it would just add extra places for people to trip over that aren't actually real bugs.
could be final
@abarth Doesn't this mean that textAligns other than left won't work when softWrap is false?

In principle it should work because this is just the max width.  We layout the text twice: once to get the intrinsic width and once at that width (subject to these constraints).

With libtxt, we can do this more efficiently because we'll be able to compute the intrinsic sizes without actually doing a fully layout.
But if softWrap is false, we always lay out at infinity width, even when we do the actual "real" layout, and then if text-align isn't left, the text ends up infinitely far to the right, no?
We layout with a max width of infinite, that doesn't mean the width will end up as infinity.
so if softWrap is false, and you overflow, you'll be aligned relative to an arbitrary point off the edge, but otherwise it'll work. I see. That makes sort of sense I guess.
hmm, this is a problem. Can you file a bug on me to take a closer look at this?
Filed https://github.com/flutter/flutter/issues/4413
should we export TextBox?
It's pretty obscure.  I guess we could.
Let's skip the vertical fade.  It's even less clear how it should work than the horizontal fade.
Nevermind.  >):
Why a return here but a break below?

accident of how i wrote the code, though i can justify it post-hoc: the "return" is an early return (nothing changed, bail out), whereas the other two branches are actually doing something. If we ever add something after the switch, I'd expect the identical/metadata cases to do nothing, but the other cases to do it.
fwiw, i'd probably use the getters rather than the fields, mostly for readability. your call.
This will need dartdocs.
oh, also, if Locale is part of your API, you should reexport it, so that users of your API don't have to import dart:ui
Why not do this as the first thing in the method?
Oops that's what I meant it to do.
Do we not allow the recognizer to be any of the other types of GestureRecognizers?
Currently we don't - I think we should fix that, but we should do it with something that will probably be breaking.
I'm not really sure what "and RenderObject is in immutable state at this point" means here.
The ideal solution here will be removing RenderObject from the children, but we can't since the renderobject is locked after layout phase
do we want to set the offsets to null for the children that aren't being laid out this time? otherwise we'll have out of date offsets
is there a situation that we use offsets for children that are not painted? It sounds to me that we should really remove this children if it is not painted.
Add a test for this?
Done
same here
Fixed.
Might be worth adding non-public documentation explaining why this is needed.
done
Do you need the `== true`?
Yeah, it is needed here. `_cachedChildNodes` may be null and then `_cachedChildNodes?.isNotEmpty` is also null, which is not a valid boolean expression.
Oh of course, got it.

why don't we directly cache the reference of `newChildren` but create a new cache queue? It also seems weird we cache the entire semantics node so that we can reuse the id. Can we expose the method to set the id for the semantics node? If not, it seems like we should fix the castOS to deal with changing id?

All RenderObject's cache their entire SemanticsNode in RenderObject._semantics to re-use ids. This method was kinda unusual because it didn't cache things.
The SemanticsNode takes over ownership of newChildren in SemanticsNodes.updateWith, so nobody outside of it should really be holding onto that list (nor modify it later).
I don't think it's unreasonable to expect stable IDs for SemanticsNodes that don't change. So castOS's expectation here seems fine.
I see, I wasn't aware other renderobjects are caching the node.
Maybe: must be one of Tap/Longpress?
Assets can be caught in unit tests too, just saying :)
I didn't want to be too specific here, as I don't see why we cant support DoubleTap or MultiTap as well. If we add it shortly, then that would be overly specific and not strictly correct
@GaryQian I wonder why do we need _textPainter.inlinePlaceholderScales? aren't they always the same as textScaleFactor?

I believe that in actual use cases, it is indeed true, but it is also possible (at lower levels) to independently set them. This may or may not be necessary at this level, I can look into it to see if it is safe to remove.
The scales are added into the list through WidgetSpan.build() which gets its value from the textScaleFactor. I couldn't find a possible way to have a different textscalefactor.

Any of these docs comments that were copied from text_painter.dart should use a macro instead.

Here's an example of how to do that:

https://github.com/flutter/flutter/blob/0bb1e573fce0a32c28d1bd3caf26e53405604f48/packages/flutter/lib/src/painting/text_painter.dart#L335-L337

https://github.com/flutter/flutter/blob/0bb1e573fce0a32c28d1bd3caf26e53405604f48/packages/flutter/lib/src/rendering/paragraph.dart#L269
Thanks for the examples!
If children is empty (seen in the example app posted in the bug and in the test case, this throws an exception)

There seem valid cases where childIndex < children.length.

In my test where this used to crash, I get childIndex: 2, children.length 7, placeholderIndex: 8 at this point, as a reference.
That is unexpected, we have to annotate all the semantics children, or they may not have the correct semantics. Do you have a repro example?
Does my complicated example help? That is pretty close to what customer:money is actually doing. https://github.com/flutter/flutter/issues/69787#issuecomment-722169455
yes, this pr missed this use case, I will update it to make sure it works
Also feel free to ping me on chat if would be helpful, happy to walk through it or help dig. I don't have a simple setup, but have a snapshot with the above crash.

I think I've applied the right patch, but it is now asserting on this line for the case where it wasn't crashing before.

For the case that was crashing, childIndex == children.length == 0, which is where it used to have 7 children expecting 8.  Immediately after that case, childIndex comes out == 0 but children.length == 8 and this asserts.
will reach out offline

update: patch wasn't right.

Confirmed this fixes the crash.
trivial nit: comma is extraneous here i believe
